title: Can I file a bankruptcy and it not affect my wife?
question: So I am looking at clearing some debt that I have all on my own. But I don’t want it to affect my wife’s credit in any way. Is that possible for me to do. My wife owned her home and I’m not listed on her deed or Loan papers at all.
answers:
There are parts to this puzzle that aren't in your question. As mentioned by others, there are income and community property questions to consider, not just credit scores.

I strongly recommend that you have a consultation (usually free) with an experienced bankruptcy attorney. Many attorneys will handle these over the phone if it is more convenient for someone. This is the only way you can really explore how this would owrk for you (and your wife).

If you have separate debts and she does not file with you, your filing is not going to effect her credit. On the other hand, if a loan or purchase requires both incomes, your credit may be limit the joint ability to borrow or finance. Your credit either is bad or is going to be bad even if you don't file a bankruptcy. Properly used, bankruptcy is actually "damage control." That is because you can rebuild your credit after bankruptcy while you cannot even start if you don't file.

I have handled many situations like yours in the 40+ years I have been in practice with people who need to be cleared for security passes. I have never seen one that was a problem. In fact, you are more likely to be allowed after you file bankruptcy as you are no longer a security risk. With the debts you describe, you have more of a chance to get the job when you have discharged your debts than if you have not done so.

While you are protected from discrimination as to government benefits or even keeping a job, there is an issue when it comes to getting hired. You can be discriminated against for private business when it comes to hiring practices. Again you must consider what happens when you have a background check that shows significant debt that you cannot pay. The damage is done when you default on the debts and are a security risk. The bottom line is that you are still no worse off and likely much better off after you have filed and the debts discharged.

Government entities follow the rule that you cannot be discriminated against because you filed Bankruptcy. However, you can always be discriminated against because of the debt you owed. File your case. Get the discharge. Rebuild your credit You will be way ahead of the game. That includes getting a job with law enforcement.

You can certainly file bankruptcy alone, but you have to take wife's income into account for means test and the value of the community property for the exemptions analysis. See a bk lawyer for details. Bankruptcy will not create an issue for a background check for a potential job. Lots of debt is a far worse scenario.

In a chapter 7 bankruptcy all of the community property belongs in the bankruptcy estate. If your wife used community funds, earnings while married, to pay for your residence, then you have a community property interest in your residence and if there is non exempt equity, the non exempt equity becomes property of your bankruptcy estate.
If you file a chapter 13, all non exempt community property increases the amount of your monthly plan payment if you are keeping the residence.
In both chapter 13 and chapter 7, you must disclose your total household income, so if your wife works her income and expenses are disclosed on your petition.
You must always watch your credit report because credit bureaus are notorious for posting wrong information. Each bureau has instructions to dispute debt that does not belong on your credit report, such as your bankruptcy for your separate debts does not belong on your wife's credit report.
If you truly want to protect your wife's home you need to sit down with a knowledgeable bankruptcy attorney and discuss the facts of your case.
